text: ideally a/b testing, you need lots of data though before you can start making assumptions, I would say you don't have much right now

text: Yeah, I'm set up so I can do a/b testing.  This is my first inplay strat, so I've been deliberately cautious with how many bets it places, hence the low sample rate.  I will look to increase it at some point.

elements.text: Yeah, I'm set up so I can do a/b testing.  This is my first inplay strat, so I've been deliberately cautious with how many bets it places, hence the low sample rate.  I will look to increase it at some point.

text: you need to be aware of your impact along with feedback from your bets, the latter gets very complicated and impossible to model, ideally you start small and nudge up until your profit levels. Keep stakes as low as possible and instead think outside the box in how you can get more matched, for examples £5+ bets are massive inplay

elements.text: you need to be aware of your impact along with feedback from your bets, the latter gets very complicated and impossible to model, ideally you start small and nudge up until your profit levels. Keep stakes as low as possible and instead think outside the box in how you can get more matched, for examples £5+ bets are massive inplay

text:
I'm currently a/b testing £2 and £3 stakes and the match rates + roi are basically the same so I think that bodes well, although too early to draw conclusions.

In terms of how I can get more matched, there's a few obvious things I can still play around with, like:

• having a higher exposure limit per runner (it's pretty low at the moment, limiting it to about 1 or 2 bets per runner)
• widening the odds range I'm betting at
But taking baby steps at the moment...

text: nice, backtesting will give you a good idea of what will happen live then as long as you are realistic with stake sizes / resets etc

elements.text: nice, backtesting will give you a good idea of what will happen live then as long as you are realistic with stake sizes / resets etc

text: That's true.  I've not used the reset before - what's that?

elements.text: That's true.  I've not used the reset before - what's that?

text:
default strategy <https://github.com/liampauling/flumine/blob/cd1e981c57baef58a529b624a17a7877cc67c676/flumine/strategy/strategy.py#L52|settings> are one live order per runner, you can bump or remove this, but you also have the following on the trade/order itself:

```place_reset_seconds: float = 0.0,  # seconds to wait since `runner_context.reset` before allowing another order
reset_seconds: float = 0.0,  # seconds to wait since `runner_context.place` before allowing another order```

elements.text: default strategy
settings
are one live order per runner, you can bump or remove this, but you also have the following on the trade/order itself:

place_reset_seconds: float = 0.0,  # seconds to wait since `runner_context.reset` before allowing another order
reset_seconds: float = 0.0,  # seconds to wait since `runner_context.place` before allowing another order

text: this is to allow you to push as many orders into the market as possible but prevent the feedback / flooding the market by giving x seconds before placement etc

elements.text: this is to allow you to push as many orders into the market as possible but prevent the feedback / flooding the market by giving x seconds before placement etc

text: So what are reasonable values to use?  And are you using this just for backtesting or live as well?

elements.text: So what are reasonable values to use?  And are you using this just for backtesting or live as well?

text: strategy dependant and part of the art, anything I deploy live would have been through backtesting yes

elements.text: strategy dependant and part of the art, anything I deploy live would have been through backtesting yes

text:
Just on the reset; I have mine set to :
```place_reset_seconds=0.14```
I think that this may be too generous as Im missing out compared with other strategies that Im not running on Flumine.
What would be the lowest you could set this to, just before it becomes irrelevant? (Ie if the code takes 10ms to run then there would be no point attributing a value to the variable anyway). It would be interesting to know how low you would go with something like for the fast inplay horse markets.

elements.text: Just on the reset; I have mine set to :
place_reset_seconds=0.14

I think that this may be too generous as Im missing out compared with other strategies that Im not running on Flumine.
What would be the lowest you could set this to, just before it becomes irrelevant? (Ie if the code takes 10ms to run then there would be no point attributing a value to the variable anyway). It would be interesting to know how low you would go with something like for the fast inplay horse markets.

text: I use zero quite often, all that means is that order could be theoretically placed on every marketBook update received through the stream

text:
Also <@U4H19D1D2>, are the comments wrong here: <https://github.com/liampauling/flumine/blob/3674986e14d266acc739a8288d6c50183d42db14/flumine/order/trade.py#L32>

It says `place_reset_seconds` is the time to wait since `runner_context.reset` and `reset_seconds` the time to wait since `runner_context.place` , but isn't it the other way round?

Similarly for the docs: <https://github.com/liampauling/flumine/blob/62b40ad11988ecab039b3b822bc70779aed64bca/docs/trades.md>

elements.text: Also
, are the comments wrong here:
It says
place_reset_seconds
is the time to wait since
runner_context.reset
and
reset_seconds
the time to wait since
runner_context.place

, but isn't it the other way round?

Similarly for the docs:

text: Why do you think that?

elements.text: Why do you think that?

text:
Because `place_reset_seconds`  is being compared to `placed_elapsed_seconds` here  <https://github.com/liampauling/flumine/blob/bae349672f543d1973b706e5efb72f6bc05fd5e5/flumine/strategy/strategy.py#L154>

and `reset_seconds`  is being compared to `reset_elapsed_seconds`<https://github.com/liampauling/flumine/blob/bae349672f543d1973b706e5efb72f6bc05fd5e5/flumine/strategy/strategy.py#L163>

elements.text: Because
place_reset_seconds
is being compared to
placed_elapsed_seconds
here
and
reset_seconds
is being compared to
reset_elapsed_seconds
